newsitem.title: USA: US corporate debt mart sets buffet of new issues.
newsitem.headline: US corporate debt mart sets buffet of new issues.

text.p: The corporate bond primary sector is set to return to full swing again as players head back to their desks and line up a buffet of new offerings to feed debt-starved investors, dealers said.
"Players like where yields are...this time last year we walked into a 6.00 percent long bond," said one syndicate source.
Currently, the benchmark 30-year U.S. Treasuey bond is trading 0ff 6/32 at 96-26/32 to yield 6.75 percent.
"The market is definitely back in the swing of things...we've got a load of new issues coming to market and some others being talked about," another syndicate source.
Issuers expected to tap the market include US West Inc unit US West Capital Funding Inc, with a $2.0 billion four-part debt offering via Merrill Lynch, sources said.
"The roadshow (US West Capital) kicks off on Monday...it looks like the deal will price by the end of this week," one syndicate source said.
The A2/BBB-plus rated deal is expected to consist of five, 10, 30 and 40-year maturities, they added.
Also, Tosco Corp is expected to tap the market mid-week with a $600 million three-part debt offering via Morgan Stanley & Co, sources said.
The Tosco deal is expected consist of $200 million in 10-year debt, $300 million in 30-year debt and $100 million in 50-year debt, sources added.

Among other names circulating the market are Aon Corp's expected $700 million issue consisting of 30-year trust preferred securities which is expected to price on Wednesday via Morgan Stanley, dealers said.
BankAmerica Corp is expected to tap the market with $450 million in A1/A-minus rated trust preferred securities due 2026, sources said.
There is also talk of Phillips Petroleum Co bringing a debt offering to market as well, high-grade syndicate sources said.
In addition, TCI Communications Inc is expected to issue a $500 million in trust preferred securities via Lehman Brothers one day next week, sources added.

Turning to the high-yield sector, Tenet HealthCare is getting set to bring a two-part debt offering consisting of $800 million in notes due 2007 and $500 million in notes due 2007, market sources said.
The deal is expected to be underwritten by Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities.
Also, Multicanal SA, an Argentinian cable company, is expected to sell $250 million in junk bonds via a 144A private debt offering via Credit Suisse First Boston, sources said.
Orion Newtwork Systems is expected to bring a two-part deal consisting of $222 million in senior notes due 2007 and $100 million in senior discount notes, via Morgan Stanely.

Other junk bond issuers expected to tap the market in the coming month are Systems International, Corning Clinical Labs, Bresnan Communications, ACF Industries, Syratech Corp, Pocket Communications and Premier Parks, high-yield sources said.
New zero coupon bond deals are also expected to reappear in early 1997, after having faded for several months.

Issuers include Optelcom, which is expected to issue $150 million in zeros, General Wireless which is preparing a $220 million deal and UIH Australia/Pacific Inc which is expected to issue a $150 million zero coupon issue, dealers added.

Among foreign issuers, Argentina is expected to issue a $2.0 billion two-part global debt offering consisting of five and 20-year debt next week, sources said. Merrill Lynch is expected to underwrite the deal.

United Mexican States is expected to bring a $1.0 billion 10-year global bond via Merril Lynch and is expected to price on Thursday, syndicate sources said. They also cited talk of a $1.0 billion 10-year global issue out of the Province of Quebec, with CS First Boston is expected to underwrite the deal.
They said market rumors have Italy issuing $1.0 billion in 10-year global debt as early as January.added.
State Development Bank of China is said to also be preparing a deal of its own consisting of $300 million in 10-year yankee debt, syndicate sources said.
In addition, Colombia, Finland and Israel have been rumored to be preparing debt deals of their own in the near-term, sources added.
--Nancy Leinfuss, 212-859-1675
